summary: Email correspondence between defense attorney Martin G. Weinberg and prosecutors regarding Jeffrey Epstein's death and related legal requests. Weinberg requests DNA evidence collection from Epstein's cell, a taint review of seized emails, and asks about the government's intention to dismiss the indictment.

persons.name: Martin G. Weinberg
persons.context: Attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein's family, making preservation and production requests following Epstein's death.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Recipient of the email, appears to be involved in the legal proceedings.

persons.name: Miller, Michael
persons.context: Prosecutor referenced as having the name of another prosecutor for forwarding emails.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased defendant in the case, subject of the indictment and death investigation.

connections.description: Weinberg is acting on behalf of Epstein's family following his death, making legal requests related to the case.
Weinberg is communicating with Weingarten regarding legal matters in the Epstein case.
Weinberg is corresponding with prosecutor Michael Miller about case procedures and requests.

events.title: Epstein found dead in cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) cell.

events.title: Seizure at Teterboro
events.description: Law enforcement conducted seizures at Teterboro, presumably related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Legal requests following death
events.description: Defense attorney Martin Weinberg sends email requesting DNA collection from Epstein's cell, taint review of emails, and inquires about dismissal of indictment.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his MCC cell on August 10, 2019.
Defense attorney Martin Weinberg requested DNA be lifted from ligatures and/or bed stripping found in Epstein's cell.
Weinberg requested a taint review of emails seized from Teterboro on August 6 and from Epstein's NYC residence.
Weinberg inquired whether the government intended to move to dismiss the indictment against Epstein.
